name: (1E)-1-bicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-ylidenepropan-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1310

name: (1E)-1-bicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-ylidenepropan-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1310
Reason: The target compound consists of a bicyclic structure related to norbornene (bicyclo[2.2.1]hepta-2,5-diene) which provides a basic reference point for the melting point estimation. Norbornene has a melting point of approximately 88 degrees Celsius. The bicyclic structure induces strain and rigidity which can raise the melting point compared to non-cyclic alkanes. However, the presence of the extended π-system as seen from the 'bicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien' part can result in additional pi-pi interactions which can further raise the melting point. A phenyl ring typically raises the melting point by about 30 degrees Celsius due to π-π interactions and increased molecular symmetry. The alkenyl linkage (vinyl group) doesn't significantly alter the melting point, but the carbonyl group attached to the bicyclic structure will cause a moderate increase in the melting point, possibly by 20-30 degrees Celsius, due to the polar nature of the C=O bond and possible hydrogen bonding with adjacent molecules. Considering the target compound has an alkenyl and a carbonyl group instead of two alkenes like in norbornene, I predict that the melting point will be slightly lower than that of norbornene due to lessened symmetry and less effective pi-pi interactions. The breakdown is as follows: base bicyclic structure similar to norbornene melting point: +88 degrees, alteration due to extended π-system and phenyl ring: +30 degrees, contribution due to the carbonyl group's polar nature: +20 degrees. The actual value of 79 indicates that the carbonyl group's effect was overestimated.
